channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: They Were Entitled to Free Care. Hospitals Hounded Them to Pay.
item.description: With the help of a consulting firm, the Providence hospital system trained staff to wring money out of patients, even those eligible for free care.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mel Haasch; Photographs by Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times

item.title: How a Hospital Chain Used a Poor Neighborhood to Turn Huge Profits
item.description: Bon Secours Mercy Health, a major nonprofit health system, used the poverty of Richmond Community Hospital’s patients to tap into a lucrative federal drug program.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mel Haasch; Photograph by Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times

item.title: In Ukraine’s South, Fierce Fighting and Deadly Costs
item.description: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at an entrenched position this month near the Kherson front.

item.title: G.O.P. Senate Candidates Race to Close Fund-Raising Gap With Democrats
item.description: Their fund-raising dwarfed by their Democratic rivals, Republican nominees including Blake Masters and Mehmet Oz have been in Washington gathering cash from lobbyists.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blake Masters, the Republican nominee for Senate in Arizona, meeting voters in Sun City West, Ariz., in June. This week, he has been in Washington trying to make up a large fund-raising gap with his opponent, Senator Mark Kelly.

item.title: McCarthy Pitches a G.O.P. Agenda With Broad Appeal
item.description: Weeks before the midterm elections, the House minority leader presented a platform of neutral-sounding ideas that he said would guide a Republican majority. The hard right was there to cheer him on.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, joined with other House Republicans to unveil their “Commitment to America” agenda in Monongahela, Pa.

item.title: How Paul LePage, Running to Lead Maine, Benefited From Florida Tax Breaks
item.description: Mr. LePage, a former governor who is seeking to reclaim the office, has along with his wife benefited from property tax breaks reserved for permanent Florida residents, public records show.
item.dc:creator: Alyce McFadden and Michael C. Bender
item.media:description: As he runs for governor of Maine, Paul LePage has pushed to phase out the state’s income tax, saying the move is necessary to stop wealthy residents from moving to Florida.

item.title: Iran Protests Surge to Dozens of Cities
item.description: Iranians fed up with oppressive rules and a battered economy have faced bullets, tear gas and arrests to demand an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: Louise Fletcher, 88, Dies; Oscar Winner for ‘One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest’
item.description: She was largely unknown to the public when she was cast as what the American Film Institute called one of cinema’s most memorable villains.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.category: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (Book)
item.media:description: Louise Fletcher in 1976, when she won an Academy Award for her performance in “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.”

item.title: For Suburban Texas Men, a Workout Craze With a Side of Faith
item.description: In Katy, outside Houston, many men have taken up F3, a no-frills fitness group where members push themselves physically but also bond emotionally.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham and Meridith Kohut
item.media:description: About 30 men praying together after an F3 workout at Katy City Park in Katy, Texas. Although F3 is ostensibly nonsectarian, many groups have a Christian emphasis.

item.title: Some Women Fear Giorgia Meloni’s Far-Right Agenda Will Set Italy Back
item.description: Some fear that the hard-right politician, whose party is expected to be the big winner in the election on Sunday, will continue policies that have kept women back.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni often talks with pride about how she started the Brothers of Italy party and rose to the top of national politics without any special treatment.

item.title: What You Need to Know About Italy’s Elections
item.description: The elections could produce the first government led by a woman and by a hard-right party with post-Fascist roots.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Italy’s national elections on Sunday come after the national unity government of Prime Minister Mario Draghi collapsed in July amid a revolt in his coalition.

item.title: Sheryl Lee Ralph Is Glowing
item.description: The “Abbott Elementary” star is fresh off an Emmy win that was a long time coming.
item.dc:creator: Jamal Jordan
item.media:credit: Michael Tyrone Delaney for The New York Times

item.title: Putin and Trump, the Solo Soulless Saboteurs
item.description: Putin and Trump, dragging the world down with them.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

item.title: Want to Understand the 2022 Midterms? Meet Joe and Marie.
item.description: This congressional race in Washington State shows the November elections in microcosm.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times

item.title: This Threat to Democracy Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Trump and his allies are trying to take over the machinery of American elections.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by Stephen Maturen, via Getty Images

item.title: How Do You Handle a Wounded Putin?
item.description: You push him back in Ukraine, but slowly.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks

item.title: Liz Truss’s Tax Cuts Won’t Help Britain’s Economy
item.description: A new prime minister with bad old ideas shocks markets.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: Hilary Mantel Was the Magician and the Spell
item.description: Part of the particular wonder of reading her is the knowledge that no one else has ever written like that before nor will again.
item.dc:creator: Kamila Shamsie

item.title: Fed Chairs Are People, Too
item.description: Economic theory alone may not explain Jerome Powell’s actions.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by mikroman6 and Andrii-Oliinyk via Getty Images

item.title: What Issue Is Most On Your Mind for the Midterm Elections?
item.description: We want to know what’s motivating your vote ahead of Election Day.
item.dc:creator: New York Times Opinion

item.title: How to Slow Down
item.description: In an age of instant everything, drawing invites us to slow down and appreciate the world around us.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Doctor Burns Out: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Dates With a Book, Meals for Roller Skaters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking to celebrate a quiet birthday on your own? No problem.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: The World Cup Is a Feeling, One That Money Can’t Buy
item.description: The tournament is, at heart, a feeling, and FIFA and Qatar may be forgetting that no amount of spending is a substitute.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: What happens when the World Cup is built for selfies, not supporters?

item.title: ‘Somebody Planted the Guns’: In Canada, a Raided, Distrusting Village Blames the Police
item.description: When a cache of weapons was found in a tiny Canadian village that has become a symbol of the far right, it didn’t take long for new conspiracy theories to start circulating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Coutts, Alberta, on the border with Montana, was the site of a large weapons seizure and of antigovernment protests this winter.

item.title: The Discount Data That Some Colleges Won’t Publish
item.description: Want to know how few students pay full price, or the odds of getting merit aid? The so-called Common Data Set can help, but some schools don’t post it.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber

item.title: The Fight Between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Explained
item.description: The hostilities that flared again last week reflect decades of animosity over a mountain region, but the consequences could be far wider. Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A firefighter among the ruins of a house destroyed by shelling in Sotk, Armenia, last week.

item.title: The School Shooting Is Fake. Can It Prepare an Officer for a Real One?
item.description: A $50 million facility in upstate New York is trying to teach officers the thing they’ll need most during the next mass shooting: bravery.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers practiced maneuvers in a facility designed to simulate an active-shooter situation in a school.

item.title: Is It Covid or the Flu? How to Tell Symptoms Apart
item.description: There are slight differences in symptoms, but the best way to tell which infection you have is through a test.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Fall Is the Season for Building Mindfulness and Resilience
item.description: Yes, the easy summer days are behind us. But if you’re willing to brave the chill, autumn holds a special set of rewards.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: Is It Possible to Exercise Too Much?
item.description: And if so, how can I tell if I’m overdoing it?
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Guns, Gorillas and Netflix: A Belgian Prince in Congo
item.description: Emmanuel de Merode is trying to protect Virunga National Park, catching the eye of Hollywood, and its philanthropists, along the way. “Complicated” doesn’t even begin to describe the story.
item.dc:creator: Adam Popescu
item.media:description: Emmanuel de Merode, the director of Virunga National Park, with the conservation rangers in the park.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
